channel.title: Java error T.T
channel.description:
[code]Unable to locate tools.jar. Expected to find it in C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\j re1.6.0_06\lib\tools.jar Buildfile: build.xml
runserver: [java] # [java] # An unexpected error has been detected by Java Runtime Environment:
[java] # [java] # java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: requested 2621440 bytes for GrET in C: \BUILD_AREA\jdk6_06\hotspot\src\share\vm\utilities\growableArray.cpp. Out of swa p space? [java] # [java] # Internal Error (allocation.inline.hpp:42), pid=60104, tid=67992 [java] # Error: GrET in C:\BUILD_AREA\jdk6_06\hotspot\src\share\vm\utiliti es\growableArray.cpp [java] # [java] # Java VM: Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (10.0-b22 mixed mode, sharing windows-x86) [java] # An error report file with more information is saved as: [java] # C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Desktop\Rscd v25\hs_err_pi d60104.log [java] # [java] # If you would like to submit a bug report, please visit: [java] # http://java.sun.com/webapps/bugreport/crash.jsp [java] # [java] Java Result: 1
BUILD SUCCESSFUL Total time: 4 seconds Press any key to continue . . .[/code]

item.title: Java error T.T
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

http://forum.java.sun.com/thread.jspa?threadID=747363&messageID=4281966

Exception in thread “main” java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: request bytes for . Out of swap space?
Although it appears that an OutOfMemoryError is thrown this apparent exception is reported by the HotSpot VM code when an allocation from the native heap failed and the native heap may be close to exhaustion. The message indicates the size (in bytes) of the request that failed and also indicates what the memory is required for. In some cases the reason will be shown but in most cases the reason will be the name of a source module reporting the allocation failure. If an OutOfMemoryError with this error is thrown it may require using utilities on the operating system to diagnose the issue further. Examples of issues that may not be related to the application are when the operating system is configured with insufficient swap space, or when there is another process on the system that is consuming all memory resources. If neither of these issues is the cause then it is possible that the application is failed due to native leak; for example, application or library code is continuously allocating memory but is not releasing it to the operating system.

If that doesn’t work,try poking around java forums for a while.

Read full topic
